title: Inferring a measure of physiological age from multiple ageing related phenotypes

author: David Knowles, Department of Engineering, University of Cambridge

segmentation: My name is David Nosan.
I'm going to be talking about inferring a measure of physiological age from multiple aging related phenotypes, so this is being collaborative work with lots of different groups.
As you can see from all the logos.
So I'm in Cambridge University, but this is been together with Dan Glass who's at Kings College, London.
There parts whose was at the Welcome Trust Sanger Centre and John Win at Microsoft Research.
So.
I'm going to give to give 2 levels of motivation.

The first level of motivation is really going to be connecting what I'm doing here to this idea of personalized medicine, which this workshop is all about, and then I'll give some more specific motivation for the particular problem I'm looking at.
So.
I guess coming from machine learning when I think about health, I think about.
Can I summarize an individual's health status somehow?
Can I get some low dimensional representation of how healthy someone is given a load of phenotypic or genetic data?
But having some great statistical model isn't enough.
I need something that I can explain to clinicians and the clinicians going to explain to patients.
And you might say, well, why would I?
Why would I want to do that?
So my idea there is that.

If I have some idea what the underlying latent, unobserved health status of patients that I'm trying to look after is, then I can look for patients whose health seems to be deteriorating more rapidly than you'd want, or just is spared in an absolute term.
Maybe I can go and target those individuals.

So that's kind of the big picture that I'd like you to kind of in the back of your heads while I talk about why you go through the rest of the talk.
So the specific kind of sub topic I'm going to talk about is aging so.
